SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A WEFT OF INFORMATION TO THE PERSON ANSWERING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to remember a general questionnaire on pioneer life because each individual who is asked to answer it has not only the same experiences as another, but also some which are peculiar to himself. It is therefore suggested that the answers be given in detail so that they may be of value to others.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1921, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pioneers: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Really Do?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered it, but would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ... H.A.F.E.S. (MRS.) ELIZA JANE ...
2. Your address ... 218-12th Street, Brandon, Manitoba.
3. Date ... June 30th, 1954 ...
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) BRACEBRIDGE, ONTARIO.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   ROBERT MONTGOMERY - Farmer.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   March, 1883

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Began in Muskoka 1879, July 17th.
   Moved to Portage la Prairie 1882 - Left for Saskatchewan in 1883.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   I was 3½ years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My parents took homestead land in Saskatchewan.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    I do not know how they acquired this information.
Hales, Mrs. Eliza Jane
218 - 12th Street,
Brandon, Manitoba.

1. Your full name: HAKES (MRS.) ELIZA JANE.
2. Your address: 218 - 12th Street, Brandon, Manitoba.
3. Date: June 26, 1954.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): BRACEBRIDGE, ONTARIO.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: ROBERT MONTGOMERY - Farmer.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 1883.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Berdmore, SK since 1879 - April 1883.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (If you do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.): I was in my teens.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? (My parents had promised land in Saskatchewan).
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Mail order? Government Information?): I do not know how they acquired this information.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Just spoken of as "Western Rush."

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   With my Father & Mother.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Train to Moose Jaw, back and then by Oxcart team to Manor, Saskatchewan,
   then Moose Mountain (60 miles from Moose Jaw).

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way,
   meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement,
   etc.)
   To excitement - 60 mile required 4 days travel. The valley creeks were high with water
   and many times the Oxcart team had to swim the creek with the loaded wagon.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   With Sutherland Bachelors who lived 8 miles from our homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Then Moose Mountain near Manor, Saskatchewan.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Leaving Saskatchewan in 1919, I have lived in Brandon, Manitoba since that date.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   Only 3 years old with parents when coming to Western Canada. When grown up I worked
   on the farm, milking cows, raising hay and general farm work.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? 

Only 3 years old until parents could travel to Western Canada. Then came back to work on the farm, milking cows, raising sheep and general farming work.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Parents wrote to relatives and friends just occasionally as we were at first 16 miles from Post Office.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. I was married on January 23, 1896, at Carrington Manor, Saskatchewan, to Thomas Hales.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle? No recollection of this.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

As of #9 - came west as in #7.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

When we first settled in dwelling at Moose Mountain Homestead our neighbor who were nearest to us were 8 miles distant. Our friends came in 1884 to settle just 1 mile from us. There were several days and nights of anxiety during the Red Rebellion and there were only 350 Indians on two reserves with about 4 mounted police on guard. East & West end of Mountain. The Indians were very daring on those days and have always been very frightened of Indians since that time.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We went by Oxen team twice each year to Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan for supplies, attended church in chapel from each neighbors house taking them about as often as a minister was available. Later years we attended a log church 6 mile from home. Visiting with friends quite regularly, just one mile away. Walking all storeboats Oxen.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
I have been an Church Organization and any now a life member of the Daughters Association. Our life membership certificates were taken out in 1916 to the Red Cross Association in our family.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.).
